unit_learning_outcomes.description: express properties of software languages using formal notations
evaluate the role that languages play in software development and describe a spectrum of software languages that are in current use
defend the correct operation of a language processor by construction and use of appropriate test cases
translate formal notations of software language properties into implementations of language processors

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Reading the provided notes, recommended texts, sample code and other materials.

enrolment_rules.description: 130cp at 1000 level or above including COMP2010 or COMP225 or COMP2000 or COMP229

assessments.description: This examination will assess the material from Weeks 1-4 of the semester.
This examination will assess the material from Weeks 5-8 of the semester.

The third assignment focuses on translating a language into some other form, such as another structured language (e.g., translating a programming language into a lower-level form such as bytecode or assembly language).

The first assignment focuses on using Scala (particularly its functional features) to develop a small-medium-sized program. The aim is to consolidate and assess Scala programming skills in preparation for the other two assignments.
The second assignment focuses on processing the syntax of a language to obtain a representation that the rest of the implementation can use.
This examination will assess the material from Weeks 9-12 of the semester.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: Formal languages play a central role in modern software development. Programming languages such as Java and C++ allow developers to express their algorithms and data structures. Compilers and interpreters transform programs into running software. Data languages such as XML and JSON are widely used to transfer information between systems. This unit studies software languages by looking at how they are used in software development. Students will study how to formally understand the syntax, semantics and translation of software languages. Practical exercises involve writing software language processors of various kinds such as simple compilers or data transformation tools.
data.title: Programming Languages
